entry.title: Mona Williams (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that Mona Williams (pictured) said her degree from Stanford University was called a "wanky Yankee" degree when she arrived in New Zealand?

entry.title: Man and Wolf (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that the 1992 comic book storyline "Man and Wolf", in which Captain America is transformed into a werewolf, has been described as "one of the most bizarre moments of the core Marvel Universe"?

entry.title: Abram Kofman (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that Abram Kofman was the first Ancient Greek-Esperanto translator, publishing translated sections of the Iliad in 1895?

entry.title: oral history project (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that interviews collected for a Boston College oral history project were used in two murder trials?

entry.title: Mitiarjuk Nappaaluk (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that after learning to write with Inuktitut syllabics to help Catholic missionaries learn her language, Mitiarjuk Nappaaluk wrote one of the first Inuktitut-language novels?

entry.title: Nashville Public Television (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that John Seigenthaler hosted a literary interview program which ran for 42 years on Nashville Public Television?

entry.title: Sara Daavettila (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that in high school, tennis player Sara Daavettila went an entire season without losing a game?

entry.title: Pachelbel's Canon is notorious for being widespread in pop music (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that Pachelbel's Canon is notorious for being widespread in pop music, but it actually isn't?
